org.apache.juneau.transform

Class BeanTransform<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.juneau.transform.Transform
      • org.apache.juneau.transform.BeanTransform<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - The class type that this transform applies to.
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AnnotationBeanTransform, InterfaceBeanTransform

    public abstract class BeanTransform<T>
extends Transform
    Parent class for all bean transforms.

    Bean transforms are used to control aspects of how beans are handled during serialization and parsing.

    This class can be considered a programmatic equivalent to using the @Bean annotation on bean classes. Thus, it can be used to perform the same function as the @Bean annotation when you don't have the ability to annotate those classes (e.g. you don't have access to the source code).

    Note that value returned by the Transform.forClass() method is automatically determined through reflection when the no-arg constructor is used.

    When defining bean transforms, you can either call the setters in the contructor, or override getters.

    Example

    // Create our serializer with a transform. WriterSerializer s = new JsonSerializer().addTransforms(AddressTransform.class); Address a = new Address(); String json = s.serialize(a); // Serializes only street, city, state. // Transform class defined via setters public class AddressTransform extends BeanTransform<Address> { public AddressTransform() { setProperties("street","city","state"); } } // Transform class defined by overriding getters public class AddressTransform extends BeanTransform<Address> { public String[] getProperties() { return new String[]{"street","city","state"}; } }

    The examples in this class use the setters approach.

    Additional information
    See org.apache.juneau.transform for more information.
    Author:
    James Bognar (james.bognar@salesforce.com)

    • Constructor Detail

      • BeanTransform

        public BeanTransform()
        Constructor that determines the for-class value using reflection.

      • BeanTransform

        public BeanTransform(Class<T> forClass)
        Constructor that specifies the for-class explicitly.

        This constructor only needs to be called when the class type cannot be inferred through reflection.

        Example:

        public class SomeArbitraryTransform extends BeanTransform<?> { public SomeArbitraryTransform(Class<?> forClass) { super(forClass); ... } }

        Parameters:
        forClass - The class that this bean transform applies to.

    • Method Detail

      • getProperties

        public String[] getProperties()
        Returns the set and order of names of properties associated with a bean class.
        Returns:
        The name of the properties associated with a bean class, or null if all bean properties should be used.
        See Also:
        setProperties(String...)

      • setProperties

        public BeanTransform<T> setProperties(String... properties)
        Specifies the set and order of names of properties associated with a bean class.

        The order specified is the same order that the entries will be returned by the BeanMap.entrySet() and related methods.

        This method is an alternative to using the Bean.properties() annotation on a class.

        Example:

        // Create our serializer with a transform. WriterSerializer s = new JsonSerializer().addTransforms(AddressTransform.class); Address a = new Address(); String json = s.serialize(a); // Serializes only street, city, state. // Transform class public class AddressTransform extends BeanTransform<Address> { public AddressTransform() { setProperties("street","city","state"); } }

        Parameters:
        properties - The name of the properties associated with a bean class.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • isSortProperties

        public boolean isSortProperties()
        Returns true if the properties defined on this bean class should be ordered alphabetically.

        This method is only used when the getProperties() method returns null. Otherwise, the ordering of the properties in the returned value is used.

        Returns:
        true if bean properties should be sorted.
        See Also:
        setSortProperties(boolean)

      • setSortProperties

        public BeanTransform<T> setSortProperties(boolean sortProperties)
        Specifies whether the properties on this bean should be ordered alphabetically.

        This method is ignored if the getProperties() method does not return null.

        This method is an alternative to using the Bean.sort() annotation on a class.

        Parameters:
        sortProperties - The new value for the sort properties property.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • getExcludeProperties

        public String[] getExcludeProperties()
        Returns the list of properties to ignore on a bean.
        Returns:
        The name of the properties to ignore on a bean, or null to not ignore any properties.
        See Also:
        setExcludeProperties(String...)

      • setExcludeProperties

        public BeanTransform<T> setExcludeProperties(String... excludeProperties)
        Specifies a list of properties to ignore on a bean.

        This method is an alternative to using the Bean.excludeProperties() annotation on a class.

        Example:

        // Create our serializer with a transform. WriterSerializer s = new JsonSerializer().addTransforms(NoCityOrStateTransform.class); Address a = new Address(); String json = s.serialize(a); // Excludes city and state. // Transform class public class NoCityOrStateTransform extends BeanTransform<Address> { public AddressTransform() { setExcludeProperties("city","state"); } }

        Parameters:
        excludeProperties - The name of the properties to ignore on a bean class.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • getPropertyNamer

        public Class<? extends PropertyNamer> getPropertyNamer()
        Returns the PropertyNamer associated with the bean to tailor the names of bean properties.
        Returns:
        The property namer class, or null if no property namer is associated with this bean property.
        See Also:
        setPropertyNamer(Class)

      • setPropertyNamer

        public BeanTransform<T> setPropertyNamer(Class<? extends PropertyNamer> propertyNamer)
        Associates a PropertyNamer with this bean to tailor the names of the bean properties.

        Property namers are used to transform bean property names from standard form to some other form. For example, the PropertyNamerDashedLC will convert property names to dashed-lowercase, and these will be used as attribute names in JSON, and element names in XML.

        This method is an alternative to using the Bean.propertyNamer() annotation on a class.

        Parameters:
        propertyNamer - The property namer class.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • getSubTypeProperty

        public String getSubTypeProperty()
        Returns the name of the sub type property associated with the bean class.
        Returns:
        The sub type property name, or null if bean has no subtypes defined.
        See Also:
        setSubTypeProperty(String)

      • setSubTypeProperty

        public BeanTransform<T> setSubTypeProperty(String subTypeAttr)
        Defines a virtual property on a superclass that identifies bean subtype classes.

        In the following example, the abstract class has two subclasses that are differentiated by a property called subType

        // Abstract superclass public abstract class A { public String f0 = "f0"; } // Subclass 1 public class A1 extends A { public String f1; } // Subclass 2 public class A2 extends A { public String f2; } // Transform for defining subtypes public class ATransform extends BeanTransform<A> { public ATransform() { setSubTypeProperty("subType"); addSubType(Al.class, "A1"); addSubType(A2.class, "A2"); } }

        The following shows what happens when serializing a subclassed object to JSON:

        JsonSerializer s = new JsonSerializer().addTransforms(ATransform.class); A1 a1 = new A1(); a1.f1 = "f1"; String r = s.serialize(a1); assertEquals("{subType:'A1',f1:'f1',f0:'f0'}", r);

        The following shows what happens when parsing back into the original object.

        JsonParser p = new JsonParser().addTransforms(ATransform.class); A a = p.parse(r, A.class); assertTrue(a instanceof A1);

        This method is an alternative to using the Bean.subTypeProperty() annotation on a class.

        Parameters:
        subTypeAttr - The name of the attribute representing the subtype.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • getSubTypes

        public LinkedHashMap<Class<?>,String> getSubTypes()
        Returns the subtypes associated with the bean class.
        Returns:
        The set of sub types associated with this bean class, or null if bean has no subtypes defined.
        See Also:
        setSubTypeProperty(String)

        public BeanTransform<T> setSubTypes(LinkedHashMap<Class<?>,String> subTypes)
        Specifies the set of subclasses of this bean class in addition to a string identifier for that subclass.
        Parameters:
        subTypes - the map of subtype classes to subtype identifier strings.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).
        See Also:
        setSubTypeProperty(String)

        Parameters:

      • getInterfaceClass

        public Class<?> getInterfaceClass()
        Returns the interface class associated with this class.
        Returns:
        The interface class associated with this class, or null if no interface class is associated.
        See Also:
        setInterfaceClass(Class)

      • setInterfaceClass

        public BeanTransform<T> setInterfaceClass(Class<?> interfaceClass)
        Identifies a class to be used as the interface class for this and all subclasses.

        Functionally equivalent to using the Bean.interfaceClass() annotation.

        When specified, only the list of properties defined on the interface class will be used during serialization. Additional properties on subclasses will be ignored.

        // Parent class public abstract class A { public String f0 = "f0"; } // Sub class public class A1 extends A { public String f1 = "f1"; } // Transform class public class ATransform extends BeanTransform<A> { public ATransform() { setInterfaceClass(A.class); } } JsonSerializer s = new JsonSerializer().addTransforms(ATransform.class); A1 a1 = new A1(); String r = s.serialize(a1); assertEquals("{f0:'f0'}", r); // Note f1 is not serialized

        Note that this transform can be used on the parent class so that it transforms to all child classes, or can be set individually on the child classes.

        This method is an alternative to using the Bean.interfaceClass()} annotation.

        Parameters:
        interfaceClass - The interface class.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • getStopClass

        public Class<?> getStopClass()
        Returns the stop class associated with this class.
        Returns:
        The stop class associated with this class, or null if no stop class is associated.
        See Also:
        setStopClass(Class)

      • setStopClass

        public BeanTransform<T> setStopClass(Class<?> stopClass)
        Identifies a stop class for this class and all subclasses.

        Functionally equivalent to using the Bean.stopClass() annotation.

        Identical in purpose to the stop class specified by Introspector.getBeanInfo(Class, Class). Any properties in the stop class or in its baseclasses will be ignored during analysis.

        For example, in the following class hierarchy, instances of C3 will include property p3, but not p1 or p2.

        public class C1 { public int getP1(); } public class C2 extends C1 { public int getP2(); } @Bean(stopClass=C2.class) public class C3 extends C2 { public int getP3(); }

        Parameters:
        stopClass - The stop class.
        Returns:
        This object (for method chaining).

      • readProperty

        public Object readProperty(Object bean,
                           String name,
                           Object value)
        Subclasses can override this property to convert property values to some other object just before serialization.
        Parameters:
        bean - The bean from which the property was read.
        name - The property name.
        value - The value just extracted from calling the bean getter.
        Returns:
        The value to serialize. Default is just to return the existing value.

      • writeProperty

        public boolean writeProperty(Object bean,
                             String name,
                             Object value)
        Subclasses can override this property to convert property values to some other object just before calling the bean setter.
        Parameters:
        bean - The bean from which the property was read.
        name - The property name.
        value - The value just parsed.
        Returns:
        true if we set the property, false if we should allow the framework to call the setter.
